phrase.t: This page displays the settings that are currently configured on the phone.

You can log various events to the flash file system and to the provisioning server. You can configure the amount, type, and frequency of logging, as well as the software sub-system components you want to log events for.

Global Settings enable you to establish log settings for all of the log types. In Log File Upload you can specify logging frequency and the append options. In Module Log Level Limits, you can specify a logging level for each type of log. Modifying the logging levels of individual components enables you to capture low severity events in one part of the application while capturing high severity events for other components. Note that when you choose a log level, you are including all events of a greater severity level and excluding events of a lower severity level. The logging level you choose determines the lowest severity of events that will be logged.

Individual log level settings available in Module Log Level Limits cannot be logged at a severity level lower than the level set in Global Log Level Limit. Note that changing default logging levels for individual sub-systems is generally required for troubleshooting purposes only. Excessive logging levels (for example, Event 1 or Debug) can cause performance issues on the phone. You should not change the default logging levels unless directed to by Polycom Technical Support.

The Simple Setup menu provides access to the minimum configuration options you need to set to configure your phone to function properly. When you click the Simple Setup menu on the main navigation menu bar, the Language, Time Synchronization, SIP Server, SIP Outbound Proxy, and SIP Line Identification options are displayed. These options are also located elsewhere in the Web Configuration Utility. Any settings or options you apply in the Simple Setup menu are automatically applied in the other areas.

You can set the following configurations:
Language - Set the language displayed on the phone.
User Preferences - Enable or disable basic phone preferences.
phrase.t.DUO:
You can set the following configurations:
Connect Mode - Specify the type of device connected to the 2.5 mm jack on the phone. Devices connected to this jack play audio through the phone and can be connected to conferences.
Country - Specify the country the phone is located in.
Language - Set the language displayed on the phone.
User Preferences - Enable or disable basic phone preferences.

phrase.t: Displays a history of missed, received, and placed calls.

You can add custom ringtones to your phone, and you can apply custom ringtones to specific contacts or phone lines. The phones support the following .wav file formats: G.711u-law, G.711a-law, G.722, G.729AB, Lin16, and iLBC.

To add an audio file to the list, click the Add Audio file icon. You can upload an audio file from your PC or enter a URL pointing to an audio file. Audio files should have a .wav extension name. If you select a file, it will be stored in the phone's flash memory and a copy will be made to the provisioning server. If you select a URL, the phone will download the audio file from that URL. You can save a maximum of 24 audio files or until the phone runs out of memory.

Audio files that you upload are added to the list. To remove an audio file, select the audio file name in the list and click the Delete Audio File icon. To play an audio file, select the audio file name and click on the Play Audio file icon.

You can set a custom ringtone as the welcome sound in the Welcome Sound drop down box and for incoming calls using the Ring Type drop down box. To apply custom ringtones to specific contacts, on your phone, go to Menu > Features > Contact Directory, select a contact, press the Edit soft key, and choose Ring Type.

To apply a custom ringtone to a line, on your phone, go to Utilities > Soft Key & Line Key Configuration, select the line you wish to apply the custom ringtone to, and choose a ringtone type using the Edit Speed Dial Contact options.

Note: If you configure an unsupported audio file, the phone will use the default ringtone.

You can configure the phone to send messages to the provisioning server at regular intervals to ensure the connection between the two is operating. These 'keep-alive' messages enable the phone to detect a failed connection and re-register with the provisioning server.

This page contains settings for a group of low-level video codec parameters. For most use cases, the default values will be appropriate. Polycom does not recommend changing the default values unless specifically advised to do so.

Quality of Service (QoS) settings configure network traffic to flow in guaranteed ways. For example, QoS settings determine which data packets have priority in a data flow, or which ones should arrive at a destination without having to be transmitted again.

You can choose the background image that displays on the phone and on the expansion modules. You can use any JPEG, BMP, or PNG images.
To preview images currently stored on the provisioning server, click on a file name in the Phone Image list. The image displays in Preview Phone (landscape view) and Preview Expansion Module (portrait view).

The phone stores a maximum of six images and to change a background image, you may need to remove an existing image. To remove an image, click on an image file name from the Phone Image list, and click the Delete background image icon. The image is removed from the list.

To upload a new image, click on the Add a new background image icon. A popup dialog opens and you can choose an image file from your PC or enter a file name/URL. When you choose a new image, the image name will display in the list.

If you want to reset to the default images, click the Reset to Default button.

The settings on the Time & Date menu enable you to set the time and date display on the phone. You can choose the SNTP server used by the phone to obtain the time and date, the display format for the time and date, as well as the start and end dates the phone uses to calculate daylight savings.

You have the option of disabling all phone keys by locking the phone. This prevents unauthorized outgoing calls, allows only authorized people to answer calls, and prevents people from viewing phone information. You choose when the phone keys are locked and specify authorized phone numbers a locked phone can call. If you enable the phone lock feature, a soft key is available on the phone to prompt you for a user password. The default user password is 123.
Rebooting the phone updates the phone's configuration, clears all call lists, and restarts the phone.

For phones that use Transport Layer Security (TLS), cipher suites can be used to negotiate security settings for network connections. Cipher suites are a combination of authentication, encryption, and message authentication code algorithms.

The phone provides the following applications to third-party vendors to access phone information and push content to the phone:

Telephony Event Notifications - You can choose to send telephony event notifications like line registration, and incoming/outgoing and off-hook/on-hook events. Notifications are sent to subscribed URLs in XML format.

Phone State Polling - You can send network, call, and device information to the Poll URL in XML format.

Push - You can enable push messages to be sent to the phone for display using the phone's Microbrowser.
phrase.t.VVX_1500:
The phone provides the following applications to third-party vendors to access phone information and push content to the phone:

Telephony Event Notifications - You can choose to send telephony event notifications like line registration, and incoming/outgoing and off-hook/on-hook events. Notifications are sent to subscribed URLs in XML format.

Phone State Polling - You can send network, call, and device information to the Poll URL in XML format.

Push - You can enable push messages to be sent to the phone for display using the phone's Microbrowser.

Polycom Desktop Connector Client - You can connect the phone to your computer and operate the phone from the phone's screen using your computer's mouse and keyboard.

Exchange Applications- Manage exchange applications such your Exchange Calendar.

Polycom Desktop Connector Client - You can connect the phone to your computer and operate the phone from the phone's screen using your computer's mouse and keyboard.

Exchange Applications- Manage exchange applications such your Exchange Calendar.
phrase.t.SpectraLink:
The phone provides access to third-party applications and phone information:

Configure URLs -You can put Web applications on your phone's Applications menu.

Telephony Event Notifications - You can choose to send telephony event notifications like line registration, and incoming/outgoing and off-hook/on-hook events. Notifications are sent to subscribed URLs in XML format.

Phone State Polling - You can send network, call, and device information to the Poll URL in XML format.

Push - You can enable push messages to be sent to the phone for display using the phone's Microbrowser.

Exchange Applications- Manage exchange applications such your Exchange Calendar.

phrase.t: The phone has an HTML browser so you can view Web pages. There are two browsers on the phone: a non-interactive idle browser and an interactive main browser. Each of these browsers can be configured with home URLs to display HTML content.
You can configure the details of phone lines. Select a line to configure from the list on the far left window, and configure the details available in the main window.
Welcome to the %s Configuration Utility.
You can import a contact directory (a phone's phonebook) to the phone or export a contact directory to another phone in CSV format.

Before a call can be placed using the SIP protocol, you need to define certain SIP settings. These include the address of the local SIP port, the total number of calls allowed per line key, digitmap rules to apply, and the server details such as outbound proxy and server address.

You can enable or disable the phone's power-saving feature. After an idle period of time (called idle timeout) or when the phone's camera detects no motion, the phone's touch screen will turn off to conserve energy and to extend the lifespan of the phone's display screen. Both the idle timeout and the camera timeout can be configured.

This page enables you to configure the phone's line keys. To add and edit line keys, you must enable the EFK feature in features.cfg > feature > feature.enhancedFeatureKeys (enter 1 to enable). You can configure line keys to display for the phone's idle state only.

To edit a registered line, click on the line in the Active Line and Speed Dial Keys list. An editing field displays. When you have made changes, press Save.

To add a line key, press Add Line Key Function. The Line Registration and Speed Dial display by default. When enabled by a system administrator, EFK Function and Static BLF lines can also be configured to display. Choose a line key type and set up the line key by entering information into the available fields. Note that if you select Line Registration, you will be directed to another page: Settings > Lines. Click the Preview button to view your line key configuration. Press Save to create the new line key. If you want to change the information you have entered, click Reset. If you want to cancel creating a new line key configuration, press Cancel. New line keys display in the Active Line Keys and Speed Dial list.

Once you have created a new line key function, you can assign the function to different line keys on the phone. Click the left and right arrows to assign or remove a line key function. Click the up and down arrows to move a line key function to a different line key on the phone. Note that Registered Lines cannot be moved to the Inactive list.

To edit a line key, click on a line key in the Active Line and Speed Dial Keys list and edit the available fields.
phrase.t.VVX_500:
This page enables you to configure the phone's line keys. To add and edit line keys, you must enable the EFK feature in features.cfg > feature > feature.enhancedFeatureKeys (enter 1 to enable). You can configure line keys to display for the phone's idle state only.

To edit a registered line, click on the line in the Active Keys list. An editing field displays. When you have made changes, press Save.

To add a line key, press Add Line Key Function. The Line Registration by default. When enabled by a system administrator, EFK Function and Static BLF lines can also be configured to display. Choose a line key type and set up the line key by entering information into the available fields. Note that if you select Line Registration, you will be directed to another page: Settings > Lines. Click the Preview button to view your line key configuration. Press Save to create the new line key. If you want to change the information you have entered, click Reset. If you want to cancel creating a new line key configuration, press Cancel. New line keys display in the Active Line Keys list.

Once you have created a new line key function, you can assign the function to different line keys on the phone. Click the left and right arrows to assign or remove a line key function. Click the up and down arrows to move a line key function to a different line key on the phone. Note that Registered Lines cannot be moved to the Inactive list.

To edit a line key, click on a line key in the Active Keys list and edit the available fields.

phrase.t:
Codec Priority specifies the order of priority that codecs will be used in Session Description Protocol (SDP) negotiations. The order of priority is set in the 'In Use' list. The first codec in the list of codecs has the highest priority. The codecs in the 'Unused' list won't be used during SDP negotiations.
Note: Codecs that aren't supported by the device used will not be considered in SDP negotiations.

You can filter the phone's incoming RTP packets by IP address and/or port, and discard packets arriving from a non-negotiated IP address and/or port. You can also force the phone to define a specific destination transport port regardless of the negotiated port. This is particularly useful for communicating through firewalls. Since the phone supports conferencing and multiple RTP streams, you can specifiy several port ranges at the same time. The phone is compatible with RFC 1889, and the updated RFC 3550 and RFC 3551.
You can restart the phone to update the phone's configuration and clear all call lists.

The administrative and user passwords can be updated. The administrative password accesses administrative settings. The user password enables users to unlock and log in to phones.
These <>`"[]{}() characters are not allowed in password fields.

The phone uses a high-performance jitter buffer and packet error concealment system that reduces packet inter-arrival jitter, as well as out-of-order, lost, or delayed packets. The jitter buffer is adaptive and configurable for different network environments. When packets are lost, a concealment algorithm in the phone minimizes any negative audio consequences.

The phone can work with certain types of Network Address Translation (NAT). The phone's signaling and RTP traffic use symmetric ports (the source port in transmitted packets is the same as the associated listening port used to receive packets) and the external IP address and ports used by the NAT on the phone's behalf can be configured on a per-phone basis.
Use this page to configure the DTMF signaling mode, port to use, gatekeeper server address settings, and RTP media encryption for H.323 lines.

If video is enabled on the phone, you can configure several video settings. For example, you can configure whether or not the phone always transmits video at the start of all calls, how the near-site and far-site display on the screen, and the clarity of near-site video.

This page enables you to customize the phone's soft keys. To add and edit soft keys, you must enable the EFK feature in features.cfg > feature > feature.enhancedFeatureKeys (enter 1 to enable). You can configure soft keys to display for the phone's idle state only.

To assign a function to a soft key, press Add Soft key . The soft key fields display. Enter a label for the new soft key. There are two ways to add EFK functions. You can select an EFK function from the Action list box and click the Add button. Or, tick Edit Macro Code and enter the macro code for a soft key function. Press Reset to start again or Cancel to cancel the soft key macro. You can create a new soft key, or append functions to an existing soft key function. Click the Preview button to view your soft key configuration. Press Save to create the soft key. If you want to cancel creating a new soft key, press Cancel. New soft keys display in the Active Soft Keys selection box.

Once you have created a new soft key, you can arrange the soft keys on the phone screen. A soft key that displays at the top of the Active Soft Keys selection box is at the left-most position on the phone. Click the up arrow to move a soft key to the left, and click the down arrow to move a soft key to the right.

To remove your custom soft key, click Revert.

You can remove the default soft keys from the phone and the Active Soft Key selection box by checking Disable default soft keys.

You can import configuration files from PC to phone and you can export configuration files from phone to PC.

Import Configuration - You can browse and select configuration files saved on your computer and upload them to the phone.

Export Configuration - You can create a configuration file from a source and use that file to configure other phones.
This configuration sets up RTP media encryption for H.323 lines.
Parameters related to PSTN mode.
The IP Settings enable you to specify the SNTP server, the time zone for your location, the DNS server, the DNS alternate server, and the DNS domain. You can also enable or disable the serial port.
This configuration identifies the provisioning server the phone downloads software and configurations from as well as where the phone uploads logs and configuration files to.
The Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is an extensively used TCP/IP protocol to dynamically assign IP addresses to devices on a network.
Ethernet settings define how data is transmitted to and received from LANs.

USB is a general purpose host-to-device (master-to-slave) I/O bus protocol. It can easily carry network traffic, multiplexing it with other bus traffic. This can be done directly, or with a USB-to-network adapter product for networks such as Ethernet, ATM, DSL, POTS, ISDN, and cable TV.
The phone is compatible with wireless networks and will find and establish a connection to a WLAN network that is in the vicinity, and has a configuration that matches the phone.
You can configure the cipher suites to be used for TLS connections. The Null cipher suite is particularly useful for troubleshooting.

Use this tool to view phone logs, export a log file, and clear phone log files. After you choose a log file type and log level filter, click Refresh to view the most recent phone logs. Click Clear to delete phone logs from the viewing window. Click Export to export in XML format the phone logs that display in the window.

You can upgrade (or downgrade) the phone's software from either the Polycom Hosted Server or a specified Custom Server. Software versions on that server display in the Available software versions drop-down menu. The currently installed version is shown in blue; older versions are shown in red; newer versions are shown in green.

If you want to check the Polycom server for updates, choose Polycom Hosted Server. Available software versions display in the drop-down menu. Choose a software version from the drop-down menu and click the Install button.

If you want to check a custom server for updates, choose Custom Server. Enter the custom server address in the field Custom server address and click the Check for Updates button.Choose a software version from the drop-down menu and click the Install button.

When you check for updates, an XML file stored on the server tells the phone where to look for the update. The XML can specify a folder name or a complete folder > file path. If the XML specifies the complete file path, the phone checks the image for compatibility and automatically reboots the phone and updates the phone image. If the XML specifies a folder, the phone looks in the folder for the sip.ld or <partnumber>.sip.ld.

Upgrading your software via Polycom Hosted or Custom Server will override your Provisioning Server settings. Inorder to use provisioning server for phone software click on Clear Software Upgrade button

You can set the following configurations:
Language - Set the language displayed on the phone.
User Preferences - Enable or disable basic phone features.
Picture Frame settings - You can display pictures stored on a USB flash drive individually, as thumbnails, or as a slide show.
Screen saver - You can set up a screen saver to display pictures stored on a USB flash drive. The screen saver will automatically start each time your phone is idle for a certain amount of time.
Auto Answer - You can configure how the phone will automatically answer a call.
Protocol Routing - You can set up the way the call protocol is selected.

You can configure and install platform and application security certificates. You can customize the security certificates for use as platform and application profiles, and you can customize profiles for specific platforms and applications.
Backing up the phone generates a file containing all the phone's contact information and configuration settings. If required, this file can be used to restore the phone's settings.
The PTT paging feature supports two modes of operation: push-to-talk (PTT) mode and Page mode. They can be enabled independently and can be used at the same time.

Syslog is a standard for forwarding log messages in an IP network. On this page you can specify syslog details such as IP address or host name, server type, facility, and the level of events you want to log. You can also choose to prepend the phone's MAC address to log messages. The data is sent in cleartext. The syslog protocol is defined in RFC 3164.
Presence settings enable you to show your status as Away when your phone is idle. You can define the duration of time after which your status will display and as Away.
phrase.t.VVX_1500: Presence settings enable you to show your status as Away when your phone is idle. You can define the duration of time after which your status will display and as Away. You can also choose to be prompted to accept invitations or to automatically accept invitations.

This option determines which line to use to place a call. When set to Line, calls are placed using the first available line, regardless of the protocol the line uses. When set to Protocol, the first available line that uses the preferred protocol is used. If this line is not available, the first available line will be used.

This option determines which protocol to use when placing calls. When set to SIP, calls are placed using SIP. If SIP is not available, calls are placed using H.323. When set to H.323, calls are placed using H.323. If H.323 is not available, calls are placed using SIP.
This setting determines the total number of calls a Line Key can have at any one time.

All digits that you enter on the phone will be compared with the digitmap specified for this setting. If the digits match a digitmap pattern, the call will be automatically placed, without the Send key being pressed. The digitmap can specify one or more patterns.
This setting controls how long, in seconds, each pattern in the digitmap is applied.

This setting determines what happens if the digits you enter do not match a pattern in the digitmap. When set to 0, the digits are sent to the call server immediately. When set to 1, the reorder tone is played on the phone. When set to 2, no digits are sent to the call server until the Send key is pressed. The default is 0.

On certain phones, entering a # after you enter digits dials the phone number. The Remove End-of-Dial Marker setting determines if the phone should remove the final # from the digits you enter. When enabled, the final # is removed. When disabled, the final # is not removed. The default is enabled.
This setting determines how the date displays on the phone's screen. You can display the day, month, and year in a variety of formats.

This setting determines how the time displays on the phone's screen. Select 12:00 a.m. / p.m. to display the time in 12-hour clock notation (for example, 1:00 p.m.). Select 24 to display the time in 24-hour clock notation (for example, 13:00). The default format is 12 a.m./p.m.

The language you choose from this drop-down menu is the language that your phone (and the Web Configuration Utility) uses to display all screen information such as soft keys, line keys, as well as option and menu labels. Note: The language the phone displays can be set at Simple Setup > Language, or at Preferences > Additional Preferences > Language. Changes applied in one place are applied in both places.

Polycom recommends that you do not disable this setting. When enabled, the phone will write logs to its flash file system. The phone will upload the logs when a specified time period has elapsed or the phone's memory is full. Disabling this setting will stop the phone from uploading all logs to its provisioning server.
This setting determines the maximum file size (in kB) of the log buffer maintained locally by the phone. When the maximum file size is reached, log files will be uploaded to the provisioning server.

This setting determines if log files will be appended when they're uploaded to the provisioning server. When enabled, log files are appended. When disabled, log files aren't appended. The default is enabled.

This option controls how the provisioning server handles log files that have reached their maximum size limit. Select Delete to delete old log files from the provisioning server. Select Stop to stop downloading log files from the phone to the provisioning server. The default is Delete.

This setting determines the maximum size of log files on the provisioning server. When the limit is reached, log files are either deleted or no longer downloaded from the phone. The default is 512 KB.
This setting determines how frequently log files are uploaded from the phone to the provisioning server. The default is 86400 seconds.

You can specify the severity level of events that the phone performs logging for. A higher log level reduces the scope and amount of log information but increases the severity of events logged. A lower log level increases the scope and amount of log events to include events of both lesser and greater severity. The logging level set here determines the lowest severity log level that can be logged for each sub-system component.

This setting specifies how the time stamp displays in log messages. You can select from various time formats that use the following: Y-Year, M-Month, D-Day, H-Hours, M/m-minutes, S-seconds, and ms-milliseconds.
This setting specifies the URL for the idle browser's home page. This page displays on the phone's idle screen.
This setting specifies how often the idle browser refreshes. The default is 0 seconds. When set to 0, the idle browser is not refreshed. The minimum refresh period is 5 seconds.

This setting limits the total size of objects (both XHTML and images) that can be downloaded for each page. Once this limit is reached, no more images can be downloaded until the next page is requested.
This setting specifies the URL for the Main browser's home page. This page displays when you press the Applications key on the phone, or select Applications from the phone's Main Menu.

This setting specifies how long the Main browser should remain inactive before the idle screen displays. When set to 0, you have to exit the Main browser to display the idle screen. The default timeout is 40 seconds.

This option specifies when you want the status bar to display. When enabled, the status bar displays automatically when you access the Main browser. When disabled, the status bar is hidden. The default is disabled.
This setting enables you to set the address that your HTTP proxy server will use. If you don't specify an address, the microbrowser will use a normal, unproxied HTTP address.
From the drop-down menu, choose Active to spontaneously display Web content on the phone's screen, or Passive to notify you of available Web content. The default is Passive.

You can enable or disable the spontaneous display of Web content on the phone's screen. If enabled, choose Passive or Active from the drop-down box below to specify whether the Web content spontaneously displays (Active) or whether to notify you of available Web content (Passive). The default is disabled.

This option enables you to choose what the phone displays when you press the Messages key or select Menu > Features > Messages. When enabled, the Messages screen displays with a list of voicemail messages. When disabled, the menu items Message Center and Instant Messages display. By default, the Messages menu item is disabled.

You can specify the IP address displayed in SIP signaling. This allows the use of a NAT device to redirect traffic. If you want to use a NAT device, the IP address should match the external IP address that the NAT device uses.
Enter how often the phone sends keep-alive messages to the gateway/NAT device. When set to 0, the phone doesn't send keep-alive messages. The default is 0 seconds.
The RTP Port number overrides the Port Range Start value set on the RTP Port Settings Page.
Enter the port number used for SIP signaling. This port number overrides the Port value set for the SIP server.
This option determines if the microbrowser displays on a locked phone. When set to Yes, the microbrowser displays. When set to No, the microbrowser doesn't display. The default is No.

This option determines if the phone enters Do Not Disturb (DND) mode when the phone is locked. When set to Yes, the phone enters DND mode when the phone locks. If there is an incoming call, the phone won't ring. When set to No, the phone will ring when the phone is locked and there's an incoming call. The default is No.
Enter a number to determine the number of minutes the phone will idle before automatically locking. When set to 0, the phone won't lock. The default is 0.
Choose whether you want to lock the phone's keypad.
When you restart/reboot the phone, choose whether you want the default state of the phone keys to be locked or not.

This option determines if the phone's LCD screen periodically turns off to consume less power. When enabled, the screen turns off at specific times. When disabled, the screen never turns off. The default is enabled.
phrase.t.VVX_500: This option determines if the phone's LCD screen periodically turns off to consume less power. When enabled, the screen turns off at specific times. When disabled, the screen never turns off. The default is disabled.

phrase.t: This setting specifies how long the phone should be idle, during non-office hours, before the screen turns off. The default is 1 minute.
This setting specifies how long the phone should be idle, during office hours, before the screen turns off. The default is 10 minutes.
This setting specifies how long the phone should be idle after a phone event (for example, a key press or an incoming call), before the screen turns off. The default is 10 minutes.
This setting specifies how many hours you work on Friday. The default is 10 hours.
This setting specifies how many hours you work on Monday. The default is 10 hours.
This setting specifies how many hours you work on Saturday. The default is 0 hours.
This setting specifies how many hours you work on Sunday. The default is 0 hours.
This setting specifies how many hours you work on Thursday. The default is 10 hours.
This setting specifies how many hours you work on Tuesday. The default is 10 hours.
This setting specifies how many hours you work on Wednesday. The default is 10 hours.
This setting specifies when you start work on Friday. The default is 8:00 a.m.
This setting specifies when you start work on Monday. The default is 8:00 a.m.
This setting specifies when you start work on Saturday. The default is 8:00 a.m.
This setting specifies when you start work on Sunday. The default is 8:00 a.m.
This setting specifies when you start work on Thursday. The default is 8:00 a.m.
This setting specifies when you start work on Tuesday. The default is 8:00 a.m.
This setting specifies when you start work on Wednesday. The default is 8:00 a.m.

This setting specifies how sensitive the phone's camera is at detecting your presence during non-office hours. If the camera detects your presence, the screen won't shut off. You can enter a number between 0 (no sensitivity) and 10 (highest sensitivity). If you enter 0, the user detection feature is disabled. This means that the screen will turn off even if you're near your phone. The default is 2.

This setting specifies how sensitive the phone's camera is at detecting your presence during office hours. If the camera detects your presence, the screen won't shut off. You can enter a number between 0 (no sensitivity) and 10 (highest sensitivity). If you enter 0, the user detection feature is disabled. This means that the screen will turn off even if you're near your phone. The default is 7.

You can specify the Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) of packets. If you set the DSCP, you will override the other parameters specified under IP ToS. Allowed values are 0 to 63, EF, AF11, AF12, AF13, AF21, AF22, AF23, AF31, AF32, AF33, AF41, AF42, or AF43.
When enabled, the max-reliability bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is disabled.
When enabled, the max-throughput bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is disabled.
When enabled, the min-cost bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is disabled.
When enabled, the min-delay bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is enabled.
Sets the precedence bits in the IP ToS field of the IP header.

Enables you to specify the DSCP of packets. If set, this will override the other parameters specified under IP ToS. Allowed values are 0 to 63, EF, AF11, AF12, AF13, AF21, AF22, AF23, AF31, AF32, AF33, AF41, AF42, or AF43.
When enabled, the max-reliability bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is disabled.
When enabled, the max-throughput bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is enabled.
When enabled, the min-cost bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is disabled.
When enabled, the min-delay bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is enabled.
Sets the precedence bits in the IP ToS field of the IP header.

Enables you to specify the DSCP of packets. If set, this will override the other parameters specified under IP ToS. Allowed values are 0 to 63, EF, AF11, AF12, AF13, AF21, AF22, AF23, AF31, AF32, AF33, AF41, AF42, or AF43.
When enabled, the max-reliability bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is disabled.
When enabled, the max-throughput bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is enabled.
When enabled, the min-cost bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is disabled.
When enabled, the min-delay bit in the IP ToS field of the IP header is set. When disabled, the bit is not set. The default is enabled.
Sets the precedence bits in the IP ToS field of the IP header.
The cipher list used to encrypt data. Each cipher is separated by '!'.
Enter the time to wait (from 10 to 7200 seconds) before sending a keep-alive message to the call server. The default is 30 seconds.
Enter the time to wait (from 50 to 120 seconds) before sending an additional keep-alive message to the call server if there is no response to the previous message. The default is 20 seconds.
When enabled, this option uses TCP keep-alive for SIP signaling connections that use TLS transport. The default is Disable.
When enabled, RTP packets sent from a non-negotiated IP address (arriving through SDP) are rejected. If disabled, the packets are accepted. The default is enabled.
When enabled, RTP packets sent from a non-negotiated port (arriving through SDP) are rejected. When disabled, the packets are accepted. The default is disabled.
Choose a port number between 0 and 65535. When Filter By IP Address and Filter By Port are both enabled, RTP packets will arrive on and be sent on this port. The default port is 0.

Ports for media will be allocated from a pool beginning with the specified port, up to a value of (Port Range Start + 47) for voice-only phones and (Port Range Start + 95) for video phones. The value must be an even integer from 1024 to 65440. The default value is 2222.
The address of the SNTP server used by the phone to obtain the date and time.
When enabled, daylight savings rules are applied to the displayed time. The default is enabled.

This setting specifies how to calculate the daylight savings date. When disabled, the month, date, and day of the week are used. When enabled, only the month and date are used. The default is disabled.
When Fixed Day is enabled, this is the date that daylight savings starts.
The date you specify here will be the start date of daylight savings time used by the phone.
If enabled and Fixed Day is disabled, daylight savings starts on the last day (specified by Start Day Of Week) of the week in the month. The Start Date is ignored.
Choose a month to start daylight savings.
Choose the time of day to start daylight savings using the 24 hour clock.

If you want the phone to calculate daylight savings to start on the last day of the month choose Yes, and disable Fixed Day. If you do not want your phone to calculate daylight savings to start on the last day of the month, choose No.
The date you specify here will be the end date of daylight savings time used by the phone.
Choose whether you want the phone to stop daylight savings on the last day of the month.
Choose a month to stop daylight savings.
Choose the time of day to stop daylight savings using the 24 hour clock.
The time (in seconds) between Simple Network Time Protocol (SNTP) re-synchronization. The default time is 86400 (24 hours), which means the time re-synchronizes daily.

Enable or disable the Headset Memory Mode. When the Headset Memory feature is enabled, pressing the headset key on the phone’s keypad will send the audio from a new call through the headset. When you end that call, the headset key will continue to blink and the audio of all subsequent calls will be sent through the headset. To turn the Headset Memory mode off, press the headset key again.
When enabled, the user must choose between the SIP (for audio) and H.323 (video) protocols before placing a call, if they are both enabled. The default is enabled.

This controls Manual Protocol Routing (when enabled) using soft keys. When Soft Key Control is enabled, you can use soft keys to choose between SIP and H.323 protocols. When disabled, soft keys are not available for protocol routing. The default is enabled.

When enabled, the Message Center voice mail summary screen is bypassed and voice mail is dialed immediately. When disabled, the Message Center voice mail summary screen is shown before voice mail can be dialed. The default is disabled.
The path of the USB flash drive folder containing the Picture Frame images.
The amount of time (from 3 to 300 seconds) to display each image in a slide show before showing the next image. The default is 5 seconds.
The amount of time (from 1 to 9999 minutes) to wait while the phone is inactive before displaying the screen saver. The default is 15 minutes.

When enabled, names from the local contact directory will be used to identify contacts in the local directory. When disabled, names provided through network signaling will be used to identify all contacts. The default is disabled.
When enabled, the welcome sound effect is played when you power up the phone (also called a cold boot).
When enabled, the welcome sound effect is played after you reboot or restart the phone (also called a warm boot).
When enabled, video transmission from the near site begins when a call starts. When disabled, video transmission does not begin until the far site starts. The default is enabled.
The call rate (from 128 to 1024 kbps) used initially to negotiate the bandwidth for a video call. The default value is 512 kbps. This value cannot exceed the maximum call rate.
The brightness level of video captured by the local camera. The default is Moderate.
The contrast level of video captured by the local camera. The default is No Contrast.

This avoids camera flicker at the specified frequency. Choose from:
Auto - The flicker avoidance frequency is set automatically.
50Hz - The AC power frequency for Europe and Asia.
60 Hz - The AC power frequency for North America.
The default is Auto.
Sets the fixed frame rate (in frames per second) from 5 (least smooth) to 30 (most smooth). The default is 25.
The saturation level of video captured by the local camera. The default is Moderate.
The sharpness level of video captured by the local camera. The default is Moderate.
When enabled, all sent and received calls use video (when available). When disabled, all calls are audio only, and video processing options are not applicable. The default is enabled.
When enabled, the local camera view is shown in full screen video calls. When disabled, only the far site view is shown. The default is enabled.

If Full Screen is enabled, you can set how the local view displays in the full screen.
Side by Side displays the local camera view next to far-site video.
PIPdisplays the local camera picture-in-picture overlapping the far-site video.
The default is Side By Side.
Sets the maximum network bandwidth (from 128 to 1024 kbps) that can be used in a call. The default is 768 kbps. The Call Rate (controlled by the user) cannot exceed the maximum call rate.
Specify the frame rate divider that the phone uses when negotiating CIF resolution for a video call. You can enter a value between 0-4. To disable, enter ‘0’. The default frame rate divider is ‘1’.

Specify the frame rate divider that the phone uses when negotiating Quarter CIF resolution for a video call. You can enter a value between 0-4. To disable, enter ‘0’. The default frame rate divider is ‘1’.
Enable or disable Annex D when negotiating video calls.
Specify the frame rate divider that the phone uses when negotiating CIF resolution for a video call. You can enter a value between 0-32. To disable, enter ‘0’. The default frame rate divider is ‘1’.

Specify the frame rate divider that the phone uses when negotiating Quarter CIF resolution for a video call. You can enter a value between 0-32. To disable, enter ‘0’. The default frame rate divider is ‘1’.

Specify the frame rate divider that the phone uses when negotiating Sub Quarter CIF resolution for a video call. You can enter a value between 0-32. To disable, enter ‘0’. The default frame rate divider is ‘1’.
Specify the frame rate divider that the phone uses when negotiating CIF resolution for a video call. You can enter a value between 0-32. To disable, enter ‘0’. The default frame rate divider is ‘1’.

Specify the frame rate divider that the phone uses when negotiating Quarter CIF resolution for a video call. You can enter a value between 0-32. To disable, enter ‘0’. The default frame rate divider is ‘1’.

Specify the frame rate divider that the phone uses when negotiating Sub Quarter CIF resolution for a video call. You can enter a value between 0-32. To disable, enter ‘0’. The default frame rate divider is ‘1’.
Enable or disable Annex F when negotiating video calls.
Enable or disable Annex I when negotiating video calls.
Enable or disable Annex J when negotiating video calls.
Specify the value of Annex K to use when negotiating video calls. You can enter a value between 0-4. To disable, enter ‘0’. The default value is ‘1’.
Specify the value of Annex N to use when negotiating video calls. You can enter a value between 0-4. To disable, enter ‘0’. The default value is ‘1’.
Enable or disable Annex T when negotiating video calls.

Specify the highest profile level within the Baseline profile supported in video calls. The phone supports the following levels: 1, 1b, 1.1, 1.2, 1.3. The default level is 1.3. For more information, refer to ITU-T H.264.
This sets the quality for video based on the primary usage. Choose Sharpness for video with little or no movement. Choose Motion for video with motion or movement. The default is None.

You can set the size of the video screen in regular mode. Choose from:
Normal - The video image is displayed with black bars around the image to maintain the aspect ratio.
Full - The video image is stretched to fill the entire phone screen.
Crop - The video image is cropped to maintain the correct aspect ratio.
The default is Normal.

You can set the size of the video screen in full screen mode. Choose from:
Normal - The video image is displayed with black bars around the image to maintain the aspect ratio.
Full - The video image is stretched to fill the entire phone screen.
Crop - The video image is cropped to maintain the correct aspect ratio.
The default is Normal.
Enables or disables the SIP protocol to be used for call routing, dial plan, DTMF, and URL dialing. The default is enabled.

When enabled, the proprietary 'epid' parameter is added to the From field of all requests to support Microsoft Live Communications Server. When disabled, Microsoft Live Communications Server is not supported. The default is disabled.

Enter the local SIP port to be used for sending and receiving SIP signaling packets. If set to 0 or not set, then 5060 (the default value) is used for the local port but it is not advertised in the SIP signaling. If set to another value (between 0 and 65535), that value is used for the local port and is advertised in the SIP signaling.
Enter the IP address or host name of the SIP server to which the phone will send all requests.
Enter the SIP server port to which the phone will send all requests. Choose a value from 0 to 65535. The default is 0.

Choose a transport method that the phone uses to communicate with the SIP server. There are four transport methods:
DNSnaptr (default) - performs NAPTR and SRV look-ups that discover the transport, ports, and servers.
UDPOnly - only UDP is used.
TCPpreferred - TCP is preferred and UDP is used if TCP fails.
TCPOnly - only TCP is used, or TLS - TLS is used. If TLS fails, transport fails. Leave the port field empty or set it to 5061. The default method is DNSnaptr.

When enabled, process a 200 OK response for a line-seize event SUBSCRIBE as though a line-seize NOTIFY with 'Subscription State: active header' had been received. This speeds up processing. The default is enabled.

When enabled, use SDP media direction attributes (such as a=sendonly) per RFC 3264 when initiating a call. When disabled, use the obsolete c=0.0.0.0 RFC2543 technique. In either case, the phone processes incoming hold signaling. The default is disabled.
The smallest jitter buffer depth that must be achieved before play out begins for the first time. After this depth, play out will continue even if the depth falls below this point.

The maximum jitter buffer depth supported. Jitter above this size will always cause lost packets. This parameter should be set to the smallest possible value that will support the expected network jitter.

The absolute minimum duration time (in milliseconds) of RTP packet Rx with no packet loss between jitter buffer size shrinks. Use smaller values (1000 ms) to minimize the delay on known good networks.
The preferred Tx payload size provided in SDP offers and used in the absence of ptime negotiations. This is also the range of supported Rx payload sizes.
When enabled, calls can be diverted using the Auto Divert feature, which is found in the contact directory. When disabled, the Auto Divert feature is disabled. The default is enabled.

Enter a phone number that the server will send all automatically forwarded calls to. This diversion contact number can be overridden by setting up a forwarding number to a specific contact on the phone's contact directory.
Allows or disallows the call diversion feature for shared lines. The default is yes.
Enter a number to which incoming calls will be forwarded when the line is busy. If the field is left empty, calls will be forwarded to the Diversion Contact.
When enabled, incoming calls are forwarded to the Busy Contact when the line is busy. The default is enabled.
Enter a phone number incoming calls will be forwarded to when Do Not Disturb is activated on the phone.
When enabled, incoming calls are forwarded to the Do Not Disturb (DND) Contact, if DND is activated on the phone. The default is disabled.
When enabled, you can access the call forward feature by pressing the Forward soft key. When disabled, the Forward soft key does not appear on the phone's screen. The default is enabled.
Enter a phone number incoming calls will be forwarded to if they aren't answered within the time specified by the No Answer Timeout.
When enabled, calls will be forwarded to the No Answer Contact, if they aren't answered within the time specified by the No Answer Timeout. The default is enabled.
Enter a time in seconds that incoming calls ring before they are automatically diverted.
When callback mode is set to Contact, the phone will call this number when retrieving messages.

You can configure message retrieval and notification for this line.
If set to 'registration', the phone uses its own registration number to contact the message center server.
If set to 'contact', the phone calls the message center server specified in Callback Contact.
If set to 'disabled', message retrieval and message notification are disabled.
Enter the address of the message center server your phone will send a subscribe request to after it boots up.
Enter a name or description for the associated authorized phone number. This name displays when calling from a locked phone.
Enter an authorized phone number that can be dialed when the phone is locked.

Enter a line identification address that the phone uses to register with the server. The address may include a user name, the host of the phone's SIP URI, or the H.323 ID/extension. For example, if the phone's line is 1002@polycom.com, enter 1002 as the SIP where polycom.com is the server. Or, you can enter 1002@polycom.com. Any address entered will be displayed as the phone's line if the display name and label are not specified.
Enter the password used to authenticate this line registration (if applicable).
Enter the user name used to authenticate this line registration (if applicable).
The number of calls which may be active or on hold for each line key associated with this line registration.
The display name used in SIP signaling that your phone uses as the default caller ID. This name is displayed on the call recipient's phone.
Enter the text that will display next to the associated line key. If a label isn't defined, the label will be derived from the user part of the address.
The number of line keys that will be associated with this line registration. The default is 1.
If enabled, H.323 protocol signaling is available for this line registration. The default is disabled.
This setting enables or disables SIP signaling for this line registration. The default is enabled.
Enter the line identification number you want to use for this Bridged Line Appearance (BLA). This field is available only for BLA registration. You must set Type to Shared to register a BLA line.

Choose Private or Shared line identification. If set to Private, standard call signaling is used. If set to Shared, call state subscriptions and notifications are shared with multiple phones. The default is Private.

Enter an IP address or the host name of an SIP server that accepts registrations. This address can be set at Simple Setup > SIP Server, or at Settings > SIP > Server 1. Changes applied to settings in one place are applied in both places.
The phone's requested registration period. The value must be at least 10 seconds. The default is 3600 seconds.

The requested line-seize subscription period (from 0 to 65535 seconds). This is the amount of time to play the dial tone while the phone is off-hook before going back to the idle state. The default is 30 seconds.
Enter the port of a SIP server that accepts registrations. The default is '0'.
If disabled, calls can be routed to an outbound proxy without registration.
The number of retries to be attempted before moving on to the next available server. If you don't specify a value, or the value is 0, a value of 3 is used. The default is 3 retries.

This setting specifies how often retries will be sent. If you don't specify a value, or the value is 0, the standard RFC 3261 signaling retry behavior (the default behavior) is used. The minimum value is 100 milliseconds.

Choose a transport method that the phone uses to communicate with the SIP server. There are four transport methods:
  • DNSnaptr: The phone performs NAPTR and SRV look-ups that discover the transport, ports, and servers. DNSnaptr is the default transport method.
  • UDPOnly: Only UDP is used.
  • TCPpreferred: TCP is preferred and UDP is used if TCP fails.
  • TCPOnly: Only TCP is used.
  • TLS: If TLS is used, leave the port field empty, and the phone will use 5061 by default or you can set the port to 5061. If TLS fails, transport fails.

Choose an SNTP server that the phone obtains the time from. Note: This option can be set at Simple Setup > Time Synchronization, or at Preferences > Date and Time > Time Synchronization. Changes applied to settings in one place are applied in both places.

Choose the time zone where the phone is located. Time zones are calculated by a location's offset from Greenwich Mean Time (GMT). Note: This option can be set at Simple Setup > Time Synchronization, or at Preferences > Date and Time > Time Synchronization. Changes applied to settings in one place are applied in both places.
The primary server to which the phone directs Domain Name System (DNS) queries.
The secondary server the phone directs Domain Name System (DNS) queries to.
Enter the phone's Domain Name System (DNS).
Enables or disables the serial port.
Choose the protocol that the phone uses to obtain files (such as phone software or configuration files) from the provisioning server.

Use this provisioning server if the DHCP client is disabled, if the DHCP server does not send a boot server option, or if the boot server parameter is set to Static. If using a URL, you can apply a user name and password.
The user name required for the phone to log in to the provisioning server (if required).
The password required for the phone to log in to the provisioning server (if required).
This setting specifies the number of times to attempt a file transfer. Choose a value from 1 to 10. The default is 3.

This setting specifies the minimum amount of time that must elapse between starting a new file transfer and retrying a file transfer. You can specify a value from 0 to 300 seconds. The default is 1 second.

This setting specifies whether the phone's serial number (MAC address) is included in the User-Agent header of any HTTP or HTTPS provisioning request. When enabled, the MAC address is present, when disabled, it is not. The default is disabled.

This setting determines how the phone derives its boot server address from DHCP.
  • Option66: The phone uses the accepted standard option code 66 to specify a boot server IP.
  • Custom: The phone uses the custom option code entered below to specify a boot server IP.
  • Static: The phone ignores any DHCP option for the provisioning address and instead uses the address configured above in Provisioning Server.

By default, the phone will look for a custom IP and Option 66.
When the boot server is set to Custom, you can specify the DHCP option number that the phone looks in for its boot server.
When the boot server is set to Custom, you can specify the type of DHCP option that the phone looks in for its boot server.
Choose the format that vendor-identifying information appears.
The boot server option to be used on the phone.
Enables or disables DHCP. The default is enabled.
The phone's IP address.
The phone's subnet mask.
The phone's default router.
When enabled, the phone will use the remaining configuration parameters to satisfy the various negotiation requirements for each of the EAP methods.
Enables or disables DoS Storm Prevention state ethernet packet filtering on the phone to prevent TCP/IP stack overflows caused by invalid or excessive data. The default is enabled.
Choose the speed of the network on the Ethernet.
The network speed over the Ethernet. Choose Auto, HD (half duplex), or FD (full duplex).
The selected EAP authentication method. When authenticating EAP-TLS the phone will use its pre-installed device certificate. EAP method is enabled when you enable 802.1X Auth.
Enter a user name required for 802.1X authentication. The minimum length is 6 characters.
Enter a password required for 802.1X authentication. The minimum length is 6 characters.
Enter an anonymous user name required for constructing a secure tunnel for tunneled and FAST authentications.
Enter the DHCP private option value to be used when VLAN Discovery is set to Custom.
Enables or disables VLAN ethernet packet filtering on the phone to prevent TCP/IP stack overflows caused by invalid or excessive data. The default is disabled.
If enabled, the phone determines its VLAN ID and negotiates power through LLDP.
If enabled, the phone determines its VLAN ID and negotiates power through CDP.
The DHCP private option when number when DHCP VLAN Discovery is set to custom. Available numbers are 128 -254. The default is 129.

Choose to disable DHCP VLAN discovery, or choose a fixed or custom option number.
If you choose a fixed vendor-specific option number, the VLAN ID Option field will be ignored. If you choose a custom number, enter the custom number in the DHCP VLAN Option field below. The default is disabled.
Enables or disables the USBNet feature.
Choose Disable to disable the DHCP menu, or choose Enable to disable the Static IP and NETMASK menus.
If you choose Custom as your boot server parameter, enter the DHCP option number that directs your phone to its custom boot server.
This option is disabled if USBNet-DHCP Client Enable is enabled and ignored if USBNet Enable is disabled.
This option is disabled if USBNet-DHCP Client Enable is enabled and ignored if USBNet Enable is disabled.
The default gateway IP address.
To enable Wi-Fi, click Enable. To disable Wi-Fi, click Disable.
Service Set Identifier, which is the indicative name of the network. Use alpha-numeric [1-32] characters.
When enabled, the phone connects to an Access Point which supports Cisco Compatible Extensions.
When enabled, the phone connects to an Access Point which indicates Admission Control Mandatory for the clients.
Enables you to select the Security model used in a Wi-Fi connection.
Open System or Shared key authentication.
When enabled, the phone encrypts the data frames using WEP.
Length of the key to be entered (40bit/104bit) in the Key (1-4) field.
40bit/104bit key.
40bit/104bit key.
40bit/104bit key.
40bit/104bit key.
Choose a passphrase or Hex key.
When the Key type is selected as Passphrase, enter alpha numeric characters ranging from 8-63. Or, when the Key type is selected as Hex key, enter a 64 character hexadecimal key.
Passphrase or Hex key.
When the Key type is selected as Passphrase, enter alpha numeric characters ranging from 8-63. Or, when the Key type is selected as Hex key, enter a 64 character hexadecimal key.
Alpha numeric characters, used for user identification on the authentication server.
Alpha numeric characters, used for user authentication on the authentication server.
The technique chosen by the phone to roam to a new Access point when the connection to the current Access point is lost.
Extensible Authentication Protocol method used by the phone for server and client authentication.
Enter a password, using alpha numeric characters, required for decrypting the Protected Access Credential (PAC) file.
The regulatory domain in which the phone is expected to operate.
When enabled, the phone will try to scan and establish a connection with a suitable access point in the 5GHz band, in the channels specified by the enabled sub-bands.
Enable/disable the sub-band1.
The maximum power with which phone can transmit the frames in the sub-band1.
Enable/disable the sub-band2.
The maximum power with which phone can transmit the frames in the sub-band2.
Enable/disable the sub-band3.
The maximum power with which phone can transmit the frames in the sub-band3.
Enable/disable the sub-band4.
The maximum power with which phone can transmit the frames in the sub-band4.
When enabled, the phone will try to scan and establish a connection with a suitable access point in the 2.4GHz band, in the channels specified by the selected regulatory domain.
The maximum power with which the phone can transmit the frames in the 2.4GHz band.
IP address of the server.
The UDP port number where the location update packets are sent. The default port is 8552.
Choose whether to send polling data to the configured Poll URL or the Requester. All polling data is sent in XML format.

Choose the time zone where the phone is located. Time zones are calculated by a location's offset from Greenwich Mean Time (GMT). Note: This option can be set at Simple Setup > Time Synchronization, or at Preferences > Date and Time > Time Synchronization. Changes applied to settings in one place are applied in both places.
The IP address or host name of an SIP server that accepts registrations.
The port of an SIP server that accepts registrations.
The URL to which the phone sends call processing state/device/network information. The protocol used can be either HTTP or HTTPS.
Enter the user name that accesses the state polling URL.
Enter the password for accessing the state polling URL.
From the drop-down box, choose a priority level for push messages from the applications server to the phone.
The URL of the applications server is combined with the phone address and sent to the phone's browser.
Enter a user name used to authenticate push requests.
Enter a password used to authenticate push requests.
From the drop-down menu, choose the priority of voice RTP packets. The default is 5.
From the drop-down menu, choose the priority of video RTP packets. The default is 5.
From the drop-down menu, choose the priority of call control packets. The default is 5.
From the drop-down menu, choose the priority of packets that do not have a per-protocol setting. The default is 2.
Cipher list for provisioning, if it is not configured then cipher list configured to sec.TLS.cipherList will be used.
Cipher list for SIP, if it is not configured then cipher list configured to sec.TLS.cipherList will be used.
Cipher list for corporate directory, if it is not configured then cipher list configured to sec.TLS.cipherList will be used.
Cipher list for syslog, if it is not configured then cipher list configured to sec.TLS.cipherList will be used.
Cipher list for CMA presence, if it is not configured then cipher list configured to sec.TLS.cipherList will be used.
Cipher list for browser, if it is not configured then cipher list configured to sec.TLS.cipherList will be used.
The IP address or host name of an SIP server to which the phone sends all requests.
The port of a SIP server to which the phone send sall requests.

Choose a transport method that the phone uses to communicate with the SIP server. There are four transport methods:
  • DNSnaptr: If the outbound proxy address is a hostname and the port is '0', the phone performs NAPTR and SRV look-ups that discover the transport, ports, and servers. If the outbound proxy address is an IP address, or a port is specified, the phone uses UDP. DNSnaptr is the default transport method.
  • UDPOnly: Only UDP is used.
  • TCPpreferred: TCP is the preferred transport, and UDP is used if TCP fails.
  • TCPOnly: Only TCP is used.
  • TLS - If TLS is used, leave the port field empty, and the phone will use 5061 by default or you can set the port to 5061. If TLS fails, transport fails.
The IP address or host name of an SIP server that accepts registrations.
The port of an SIP server that accepts registrations.

DNSnaptr: If voIpProt.server.x.address is a hostname and voIpProt.server.x.port is 0 or Null, do NAPTR then SRV look-ups to try to discover the transport, ports and servers, as per RFC 3263. If voIpProt.server.x.address is an IP address, or a port is given, then UDP is used. TCPpreferred: TCP is the preferred transport, UDP is used if TCP fails. UDPOnly: Only UDP will be used. TLS: If TLS fails, transport fails. Leave port field empty (will default to 5061) or set to 5061. TCPOnly: Only TCP will be used.
The phones requested registration period in seconds.
If disabled, calls can be routed to an outbound proxy without registration.
If set to 0, use standard RFC 3261 signaling retry behavior. Otherwise retryTimeOut determines how often retries will be sent. Units = milliseconds. (Finest resolution = 100ms).
If set to 0, 3 is used. retryMaxCount retries will be attempted before moving on to the next available server.
The requested line-seize subscription period.
Enable or disable the phone lock feature.
Choose whether you want to view a log displaying startup error messages.

Polycom recommends that you do not disable this setting. When enabled, logs are printed to standard out (serial and shell terminal) where they can be accessed by support personnel for troubleshooting.
This will be active only when the EAP method is EAP-FAST.
If enabled, the H.323 protocol is used for call routing, dial plan, DTMF, and URL dialing.

The local port used to send and receive H.323 signaling packets. If disabled, 1720 is used for the local port but it is not advertised in the H.323 signaling. If set to some other value, that value is used for the local port and it is advertised in the H.323 signaling.

If enabled, the phone will attempt to discover an H.323 gatekeeper address via the standard multicast technique, provided that a statically configured gatekeeper address is not available. If disabled, the phone will not send out any gatekeeper discovery messages.
If enabled, the phone will use the H.323 signaling channel for DTMF key press transmission.

If enabled, the phone will support H.245 signaling channel alphanumeric mode DTMF transmission. Note: If both alphanumeric and signal modes are enabled, the phone will give preference to sending DTMF in alphanumeric mode.
If enabled, the phone will support H.245 signaling channel signal mode DTMF transmission.
Enter the address of the H.323 Gatekeeper. This value is used if any H.323 line Gatekeeper address is empty.
The port to be used for H.323 signaling. If '0' is used, 1719 (H.323 RAS signaling) is used.
Request a time period, in seconds, after which the phone's registration with the server will expire. This value is used if any H.323 line registration time is empty. The default is 3600 seconds.
If enabled, H.235 Voice Profile RTP media encryption will be used. Media encryption will be negotiated when requested by the other line.

If enabled, and sec.H235.mediaEncryption.enabled is also enabled, media encryption negotiations will be initiated with the other line. However, successful negotiations will not be a requirement to complete the cal.
If enabled, and sec.H235.mediaEncryption.enabled is also enabled, media encryption negotiations will be initiated or completed with the other line. If negotiations fail, the call will be dropped.

If enabled, and a USB flash drive is attached to the phone, and the idle browser is not configured, a slide show will cycle through the images from the USB flash drive. The images must be stored in the appropriate directory of the USB flash drive.
Enable or disable auto-answer for all SIP calls.
Enable or disable auto-answer for all H.323 calls.
When enabled, the microphone is initially muted after a call is auto-answered.
When enabled, video Tx is initially disabled - muted - after a call is auto-answered.
Choose the ring class when the phone is automatically answered using the auto-answer feature.
Enable or disable the on-hook dialing feature. This feature enables you to dial outgoing calls while the phone is on hook.
When enabled, you can press any key on your phone's keypad - softkeys excluded - to answer an incoming call.
Enable or disable the Polycom Desktop Connector Client (PDC) feature. The default is enabled. When disabled, the PDC field options are not available.
Specify whether the PDC video screen is to the left or right of your computer monitor.
When PDC is enabled, the name of your computer displays here.
When the PDC feature is enabled, your computer's IP address displays here.
PDC uses this server port to connect to your computer.
Enter the extension of the PSTN line connected to the phone. This extension is used as a label that displays on the phone's idle screen.

You can set the duration of the hook flash. On the SoundStation Duo, this is the length of time that pressing the Conference Key cycles the phone line off/on hook. Flash timing varies by country. Choose a flash time from the drop-down menu.
This field is for enabling and disabling incoming caller ID.
Enter the URL of the download server that the phone uses to obtain software and upgrades.
Enable or disable DHCP on the wireless interface.
The IP address of the wireless interface (if not using DHCP).
The subnet mask address of the wireless interface (if not using DHCP).
The IP address of the provisioning server for the wireless interface (if not using DHCP).
Specifies which key from device.wifi.wep.key1 to device.wifi.wep.key4 is used.
The multicast IP address used to send and receive page audio.
The port used to send and receive page audio.
Emergency pages play out at maximum volume over currently active calls and over currently active pages. You cannot set or override the emergency page volume.
If enabled, call waiting behaviour is applied to new page sessions. If disabled, call waiting behaviour is not applied to new page sessions.
If enabled, all PTT protocol behaviour will be compatible with mainstream SpectraLink phones.

You can enable or disable the group paging feature. Group paging enables a phone user to send outgoing announcements - pages - to a page group. Only users subscribed to that page group will receive page messages. Click Enable to make available the Group Paging features below.
Specify the default paging group used to receive page messages. The default group is 1. Use the drop-down menu to change the default page group number.
Pages to this group are received unless Do Not Disturb is enabled or an emergency page is playing. The default priority group is 24.

Pages to this group have emergency status. Emergency pages are received by all subscribed users at the highest audio level. The audio level will return to normal for subsequent non-emergency pages. If a subscribed user is in an active call, the emergency page will be played over the active call. Emergency pages will be played out on the speakerphone even if Do Not Disturb is enabled.

When enabled, incoming pages will be played out during active calls. When disabled, incoming pages will be held until you end the active call. You can only disable pages from the Default Group. Pages from the Priority Group and the Emergency Group will still be played out during active calls.
Enter your outgoing caller ID that displays to your page group recipients.
Payload size is the length of audio contained in each RTP packet measured in milliseconds (ms).
Choose the codec to use for outgoing pages. Polycom recommends that all phones subscribed to a page group use the same codec.

Enter a time (in seconds) that page transmissions will terminate. If set to 0, the page will continue until you manually end the page transmission. When you enter a time here, an Extend soft key will display on the phone. Pressing the Extend soft key continues the time in Added Timeout by the number of seconds you enter in Continuation Timeout. The default added timeout is '0'.

Enter a time (in seconds) to add to the Added Timeout for terminating page transmissions. When you enter a time in Added Timeout, an Extend soft key will display on the phone. Pressing the Extend soft key continues the time in Added Timeout by the number of seconds you enter in Continuation Timeout. The default continuation timeout is 60 seconds.

You can enable or disable the Push-to-Talk (PTT) mode. PTT enables each subscribed user to a channel to send and receive messages to other users subscribed to the same channel. Click Enable to make available the PTT features below.
Specify the default PTT channel used to send and receive PTT calls. The default channel is 1. Use the drop-down menu to change the default channel number.
Transmissions to this channel are received unless Do Not Disturb is enabled or an emergency transmission is playing. The default priority channel is 24.

Transmissions to this channel have emergency status. Emergency transmissions are received by all subscribed users at the highest audio level. The audio level will return to normal for subsequent non-emergency transmissions. If a subscribed user is in an active call, the emergency transmission will be played over the active call. Emergency transmissions will be played out on the speakerphone even if Do Not Disturb is enabled.

When enabled, incoming pages will be played out during active calls. When disabled, incoming pages will be held until you end the active call. You can only disable pages from the Default Group. Pages from the Priority Group and the Emergency Group will still be played out during active calls.
Enter your outgoing caller ID that displays to your page group recipients.
Payload size is the length of audio contained in each RTP packet measured in milliseconds (ms).
The audio codec to use for outgoing PTT mode pages; incoming pages will always be decoded according to the codec specified in the incoming packets.
Administrators can enable or disable the availability of a PTT channel to a phone user.

Administrators can enable or disable a user's ability to send transmissions to a PTT channel. To send transmissions to a channel, both the Available and Subscribe options must be enabled for that channel group.
Administrators can determine whether users can subscribe to a PTT channel.
Descriptive label to use when announcing a page or within a page call appearance to identify the channel in use.
Administrators can enable or disable the availability of a page group to a phone user.
Administrators can enable or disable a user's ability to send pages to a page group. To send pages to a page group, both the Available and Subscribe options must be enabled for that page group.
Administrators can determine whether users can subscribe to a page group.
Descriptive label to use when announcing a page or within a page call appearance to identify the paging group in use.

Enter the URL to which telephony event notifications will be sent. Once you have entered a URL, clock on the Add button. To remove a URL, click on the URL and then click on the Remove button.

Tick this box if you want the phone to send information about which lines are registered to the call server.

Choose the type of server to look for available software versions, then click 'Check for Updates' to fetch available software. If you choose Custom Server, you can specify the server in the text field that displays.
Enter the address of the custom server to look for software updates.
Choose a software version from the drop-down menu. Currently installed version is shown in blue; older versions are shown in red; newer versions are shown in green.

Upgrades the phone software with the selected version.

Choose the default ringtone for your phone. The default ringtone is the tone you hear when receiving incoming calls.

A flag to determine whether or not EAP-FAST in-band provisioning occurs. With in-band provisioning, the handset will re-acquire credentials (see below) automatically from the RADIUS server in a wireless manner (as opposed to you downloading the credentials to the handset).

The Soft Keys that are currenlty active on phone. You can change the precendence by clicking up/down arrows.
